cluster.display: Your __________ __________ exerts precise control over many of the body 's functions, and is responsible for your awareness of some of what is happening.
Your nervous system exerts __________ __________ over many of the body 's functions, and is responsible for your awareness of some of what is happening.
The __________ __________ oversees all that we do and determines who we are.

Through a __________ __________ __________ of cells and the information that they send and receive, the nervous system can detect changes affecting the body, make decisions, and stimulate muscles or glands to respond.

Through a vast communicating network of cells and the information that they send and receive, the __________ __________ can detect changes affecting the body, make decisions, and stimulate muscles or glands to respond.

Through a vast communicating network of cells and the information that they send and receive, the nervous system can detect changes affecting the body, make decisions, and stimulate __________ or glands to respond.

Through a vast communicating network of cells and the information that they send and receive, the nervous system can detect changes affecting the body, make decisions, and stimulate muscles or glands __________ __________.
Typically, these responses counteract the effects of the changes, and in this way, the nervous system helps maintain __________.
Typically, these __________ counteract the effects of the changes, and in this way, the nervous system helps maintain homeostasis.
Typically, these responses counteract the effects of the changes, and in this way, the __________ __________ helps maintain homeostasis.
The __________ __________ is composed predominantly of neural tissue, but also includes blood vessels and connective tissue.
Neurons are specialized to react to physical and chemical changes in their __________.
__________ are specialized to react to physical and chemical changes in their surroundings.

A longer process called an axon, or nerve fiber, carries the information away from the cell in the form of __________ __________, called impulses, which allow the neuron to communicate with other neurons and with cells outside the nervous system.

A longer process called an axon, or nerve fiber, carries the information away from the cell in the form of bioelectric signals, called __________, which allow the neuron to communicate with other neurons and with cells outside the nervous system.

A longer process called an axon, or nerve fiber, carries the information away from the cell in the form of bioelectric signals, called impulses, which allow the neuron to communicate with other neurons and with cells outside the __________ __________.

A longer process called an axon, or nerve fiber, carries the information away from the cell in the form of bioelectric signals, called impulses, which allow the neuron to communicate with __________ __________ and with cells outside the nervous system.
Typically, axons within the __________ __________ are not isolated, but bundled in groups.
In the __________ __________ __________, such bundles of axons are called nerves.
In the peripheral nervous system, __________ __________ of axons are called nerves.
__________ are found throughout the nervous system, and in the brain they greatly outnumber neurons.
Neuroglia are found throughout the __________ __________, and in the brain they greatly outnumber neurons.
Neuroglia are found throughout the nervous system, and in the brain they greatly outnumber __________.
__________ we know that they have many other functions, including nourishing neurons and sending and receiving chemical messages.
Neuroglia assemble in a special, __________ __________ in the brain.
__________ assemble in a special, protective way in the brain.
An important part of the __________ __________ at the cellular level is not a cell at all, but the functional connection between a neuron and the cell with which it communicates, called a synapse.
An important part of the nervous system at the cellular level is not a cell at all, but the functional connection between a neuron and the cell with which it communicates, called a __________.
Much of the work of the nervous system is to send and receive chemical messages at __________.
Much of the work of the nervous system is to send and receive __________ __________ at synapses.
Much of the work of the __________ __________ is to send and receive chemical messages at synapses.
The organs of the __________ __________ can be divided into two groups.
The PNS also includes ganglia, which are __________ of neuron cell bodies located outside the brain and spinal cord.
The PNS also includes __________, which are clusters of neuron cell bodies located outside the brain and spinal cord.
The three general functions of the __________ __________ -- receiving information, deciding what to do, and acting on those decisions -- are termed sensory, integrative, and motor.
Structures called sensory receptors at the ends of neurons in the __________ __________ __________ provide the sensory function of the nervous system.
Structures called __________ __________ at the ends of neurons in the peripheral nervous system provide the sensory function of the nervous system.
Structures called sensory receptors at the ends of neurons in the peripheral nervous system provide the sensory function of the __________ __________.
Structures called sensory receptors at the ends of __________ in the peripheral nervous system provide the sensory function of the nervous system.
Structures called sensory receptors at the ends of neurons in the peripheral nervous system provide the __________ __________ of the nervous system.
Sensory receptors convert their information into impulses, which are then conducted along __________ __________ to the CNS.
__________ __________ convert their information into impulses, which are then conducted along peripheral nerves to the CNS.
Sensory receptors convert their information into __________, which are then conducted along peripheral nerves to the CNS.
Neurons that conduct impulses from the CNS to __________ __________ called effectors carry out the motor functions of the nervous system.
Neurons that conduct impulses from the CNS to responsive structures called __________ carry out the motor functions of the nervous system.
Neurons that conduct __________ from the CNS to responsive structures called effectors carry out the motor functions of the nervous system.
Neurons that conduct impulses from the CNS to responsive structures called effectors carry out the motor functions of the __________ __________.
__________ that conduct impulses from the CNS to responsive structures called effectors carry out the motor functions of the nervous system.
These __________ are outside the nervous system and include muscles and glands whose actions are either controlled or modified by nerve activity.
These effectors are outside the __________ __________ and include muscles and glands whose actions are either controlled or modified by nerve activity.
These effectors are outside the nervous system and include __________ and glands whose actions are either controlled or modified by nerve activity.
The motor portion of the PNS can be subdivided into the somatic and the __________ __________ __________.
The somatic nervous system communicates __________ __________ originating in the CNS to skeletal muscles, causing contraction.
The somatic nervous system communicates voluntary instructions originating in the CNS to skeletal muscles, causing __________.
The somatic nervous system communicates voluntary instructions originating in the CNS to __________ __________, causing contraction.
The autonomic nervous system communicates __________ from the CNS that control viscera, such as the heart and various glands, and thus causes involuntary, subconscious actions.
The autonomic nervous system communicates instructions from the CNS that control viscera, such as the heart and various glands, and thus causes involuntary, __________ __________.
The __________ __________ __________ communicates instructions from the CNS that control viscera, such as the heart and various glands, and thus causes involuntary, subconscious actions.
In this way, the nervous system helps maintain __________.
Despite this __________, neurons share certain features.
A neuron 's cell body contains __________ __________, mitochondria, lysosomes, a Golgi apparatus, and many microtubules.
A network of fine threads called __________ extends into the axon and supports it.
Scattered throughout the cytoplasm are many membranous packets of chromatophilic substance, which consist mainly of __________ __________ __________.
Scattered throughout the cytoplasm are __________ __________ __________ of chromatophilic substance, which consist mainly of rough endoplasmic reticulum.
Scattered throughout the __________ are many membranous packets of chromatophilic substance, which consist mainly of rough endoplasmic reticulum.
Scattered throughout the cytoplasm are many membranous packets of chromatophilic __________, which consist mainly of rough endoplasmic reticulum.
__________ __________ in neurons include glycogen, lipids, and pigments such as melanin.
Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons include __________, lipids, and pigments such as melanin.
Near the center of the neuron cell body is a large, spherical nucleus with a conspicuous __________.
Near the center of the neuron cell body is a large, __________ __________ with a conspicuous nucleolus.
In most neurons the axon arises from the cell body as a cone - shaped __________ called the axon hillock.
The cytoplasm of the axon includes __________ __________, microtubules, and neurofibrils.
The __________ of the axon includes many mitochondria, microtubules, and neurofibrils.
The axon may give off branches, called __________.
Near its end, an axon may have __________ __________ __________, each with a specialized ending called an axon terminal.
The general pattern is that neurons receive input through the __________ and the cell body, and send output in the form of an impulse conducted away from the cell body, down the axon.
In this activity, called axonal transport, movement occurs in both __________ between the cell body and the ends of the axon.
For example, enzymes required for __________ __________ are produced in the cell body and transported to the axon terminals.
For example, enzymes required for neurotransmitter synthesis are produced in the cell body and transported to the __________ __________.
In the PNS, __________ called Schwann cells encase the large axons of peripheral neurons in lipid - rich sheaths.
These tight coverings form as __________ cell membranes wind and wrap around axons.
Myelin gives the cell membranes of Schwann cells a higher __________ of lipid than other cell membranes.
Myelin gives the __________ __________ of Schwann cells a higher proportion of lipid than other cell membranes.
Myelin gives the cell membranes of Schwann cells a higher proportion of lipid than other cell __________.
The parts of the Schwann cells that contain most of the cytoplasm and the nuclei remain outside the myelin sheath and comprise a __________, or neurilemmal sheath, which surrounds the myelin sheath.
Narrow gaps in the myelin sheath between __________ cells are called nodes of Ranvier.
Schwann cells also enclose, but do not wind around, the smallest axons of peripheral __________.
Consequently, these axons do not have __________ __________.
Instead, the axon or a group of axons may lie partially or completely in a __________ __________ of a Schwann cell.
Myelinated axons conduct impulses rapidly compared to __________ __________.
__________ __________ conduct impulses rapidly compared to unmyelinated axons.
Myelinated axons conduct __________ rapidly compared to unmyelinated axons.
The white matter in the brain and __________ __________ gets its color from masses of myelinated axons.
In the CNS, myelin is produced by a type of neuroglia called an __________ rather than by a Schwann cell.
In the CNS, myelin is produced by a type of __________ called an oligodendrocyte rather than by a Schwann cell.
Thus, the gray matter in the CNS contains __________ __________ __________ and neuron cell bodies.
They descend from the same neural stem cells and remain associated throughout their __________.
__________ can also be classified by functional differences into the following groups, depending on whether they carry information into the CNS, completely within the CNS, or out of the CNS.
Neuroglia were once thought to be mere bystanders to neural function, providing __________ and controlling the sites at which neurons contact one another.
Neuroglia were once thought to be __________ __________ to neural function, providing scaffolding and controlling the sites at which neurons contact one another.
__________ were once thought to be mere bystanders to neural function, providing scaffolding and controlling the sites at which neurons contact one another.
In the embryo, neuroglia guide neurons to their positions and may stimulate them __________ __________.
In the embryo, __________ guide neurons to their positions and may stimulate them to specialize.
__________ also produce the growth factors that nourish neurons and remove excess ions and neurotransmitters that accumulate between neurons.
The four types of CNS neuroglia are __________, oligodendrocytes, microglia, and ependyma :
The four types of CNS neuroglia are astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, __________, and ependyma :
The four types of CNS __________ are astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, microglia, and ependyma :
Most brain tumors, for example, consist of __________ that divide too often.
Neuroglia that produce toxins may lie behind some __________ __________.
__________ that produce toxins may lie behind some neurodegenerative disorders.
ALS and HD affect specific sets of __________.
Identifying the roles of neuroglia in nervous system disorders suggests new targets for __________.

For example, if injury or disease separates an axon in a peripheral nerve from its cell body, the distal portion of the axon and its myelin sheath deteriorate within a few weeks, although the __________ __________ and neurilemma remain.
__________ remove the fragments of myelin and other cellular debris.
Macrophages remove the __________ of myelin and other cellular debris.
At the same time, __________ __________ along the length of the regenerating portion form new myelin around the growing axon.
Growth of a regenerating axon is slow, but eventually the __________ __________ may reestablish the former connection.
Nerve growth factors, secreted by __________, may help direct the growing axon.
If an axon of a neuron within the CNS is separated from its cell body, the __________ __________ of the axon will degenerate, but more slowly than a separated axon in the PNS.
However, axons in the CNS lack neurilemmae, and the myelin - producing __________ do not proliferate following injury.
__________ do not normally divide.
The mechanism by which the impulse in the presynaptic neuron signals the __________ __________ is called synaptic transmission.
The mechanism by which the impulse in the __________ __________ signals the postsynaptic cell is called synaptic transmission.
The mechanism by which the impulse in the presynaptic neuron signals the postsynaptic cell is called __________ __________.
Most axons have several rounded synaptic knobs at their __________, which dendrites do not have.
Most axons have several rounded __________ __________ at their terminals, which dendrites do not have.
The increased calcium concentration inside the cell initiates a series of events that fuses the synaptic vesicles with the cell membrane, where they release their __________ by exocytosis.
The increased calcium concentration inside the cell initiates a series of events that fuses the synaptic vesicles with the cell membrane, where they release their neurotransmitter by __________.
The increased calcium concentration inside the cell initiates a series of events that fuses the __________ __________ with the cell membrane, where they release their neurotransmitter by exocytosis.

The increased calcium concentration inside the cell initiates a series of events that fuses the synaptic vesicles with the __________ __________, where they release their neurotransmitter by exocytosis.
Once the __________ __________ to receptors on a postsynaptic cell, the action is either excitatory or inhibitory.
Once the neurotransmitter binds to receptors on a __________ __________, the action is either excitatory or inhibitory.
Once the neurotransmitter binds to receptors on a postsynaptic cell, the action is either excitatory or __________.
Once the neurotransmitter binds to __________ on a postsynaptic cell, the action is either excitatory or inhibitory.
This __________ is due to an unequal distribution of positive and negative ions across the membrane.
This polarization is due to an unequal distribution of positive and negative ions across the __________.
Thus, even though __________ __________ are present for sodium and potassium, the ability of these ions to diffuse across the cell membrane depends on the presence of channels.
Thus, even though concentration gradients are present for sodium and potassium, the ability of these ions to diffuse across the __________ __________ depends on the presence of channels.
Because of the __________ and permeabilities for Na+Na+ and K+,K+, we would expect potassium to diffuse out of the cell more rapidly than sodium could diffuse in.
Because of the gradients and permeabilities for Na+Na+ and K+,K+, we would expect __________ to diffuse out of the cell more rapidly than sodium could diffuse in.
This means that every __________, a few more positive ions leave the cell than enter it.
As a result, the outside of the membrane gains a slight surplus of positive charges, and the inside reflects a surplus of the __________ negatively charged ions.
As a result, the outside of the membrane gains a slight surplus of positive charges, and the inside reflects a surplus of the impermeant __________ charged ions.
As a result, the outside of the __________ gains a slight surplus of positive charges, and the inside reflects a surplus of the impermeant negatively charged ions.
This situation separates positive and negative electrical charges between the inside and outside surfaces of the __________ __________.
This situation separates positive and negative electrical charges between the inside and __________ __________ of the cell membrane.
Similarly, for every __________ moving into the cell, a Na+Na+ must move out.
A number of mechanisms move ions across cell membranes, but for our purposes we will consider the __________ __________ responsible for maintaining this balance.
A number of __________ move ions across cell membranes, but for our purposes we will consider the Na+/K+Na+/K+ pump responsible for maintaining this balance.
A number of mechanisms move ions across __________ __________, but for our purposes we will consider the Na+/K+Na+/K+ pump responsible for maintaining this balance.

Thus, the cell continues to expend metabolic energy in the form of ATP to actively transport sodium and potassium ions in __________ __________, thereby maintaining the concentration gradients for those ions responsible for their diffusion in the first place.

Thus, the cell continues to expend metabolic energy in the form of ATP to actively transport sodium and potassium ions in opposite directions, thereby maintaining the concentration gradients for those ions responsible for their __________ in the first place.

Thus, the cell continues to expend __________ __________ in the form of ATP to actively transport sodium and potassium ions in opposite directions, thereby maintaining the concentration gradients for those ions responsible for their diffusion in the first place.

Thus, the cell continues to expend metabolic energy in the form of ATP to actively transport sodium and potassium ions in opposite directions, thereby maintaining the __________ __________ for those ions responsible for their diffusion in the first place.
The potential difference across the cell membrane is called the membrane potential and is measured in __________.
The potential difference across the __________ __________ is called the membrane potential and is measured in millivolts.
The potential difference across the cell membrane is called the __________ __________ and is measured in millivolts.

In the case of a resting neuron, one that is not sending impulses or responding to other neurons, the membrane potential is termed the resting potential and for a typical neuron has a value of 70 - 70 __________.

In the case of a resting neuron, one that is not sending impulses or responding to other neurons, the __________ __________ is termed the resting potential and for a typical neuron has a value of 70 - 70 millivolts.

In the case of a resting neuron, one that is not sending __________ or responding to other neurons, the membrane potential is termed the resting potential and for a typical neuron has a value of 70 - 70 millivolts.
The negative sign is relative to the inside of the cell and is due to the excess negative charges on the inside of the __________ __________.
To understand how the resting potential provides the energy for sending an __________ down the axon, we must first understand how neurons respond to signals called stimuli.
With the resting membrane potential established, sodium ions and potassium ions continue to diffuse across the __________ __________.
With the resting __________ __________ established, sodium ions and potassium ions continue to diffuse across the cell membrane.

The negative membrane potential helps the positively charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's low permeability, but it hinders the positively charged potassium ions from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher __________.

The negative membrane potential helps the positively charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's __________ __________, but it hinders the positively charged potassium ions from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher permeability.

The negative membrane potential helps the __________ charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's low permeability, but it hinders the positively charged potassium ions from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher permeability.

The negative membrane potential helps the positively charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's low permeability, but it hinders the __________ charged potassium ions from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher permeability.

The negative membrane potential helps the positively charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's low permeability, but it hinders the positively charged __________ __________ from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher permeability.

The __________ __________ __________ helps the positively charged sodium ions enter the cell despite sodium 's low permeability, but it hinders the positively charged potassium ions from leaving the cell despite potassium 's higher permeability.
The __________ __________ balances these leaks by pumping three sodium ions out for every two potassium ions it pumps in.
The Na+/K+Na+/K+ pump balances these leaks by pumping three sodium ions out for every two __________ __________ it pumps in.

The key to understanding how this happens is the action potential, which is a rapid change in the __________ __________, first in a positive direction, then in a negative direction, returning to the resting potential.
When a neuron conducts an electrical current, that current is in the form of a series of action __________ occurring in sequence along the axon, from the cell body to the axon terminal.
Neurons are excitable ; that is, they can respond to changes in their __________.
Neurons are __________ ; that is, they can respond to changes in their surroundings.
Typically, the environmental change affects the __________ __________ by opening a gated ion channel.
If, as a result, the __________ __________ becomes more negative than the resting potential, the membrane is hyperpolarized.
If, as a result, the membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting potential, the __________ is hyperpolarized.
If the __________ becomes less negative than the resting potential, the membrane is depolarized.
If the membrane becomes less negative than the resting potential, the __________ is depolarized.
This means that the degree of change in the resting potential is directly proportional to the intensity of the __________.
This means that the degree of change in the resting potential is directly proportional to the __________ of the stimulation.
For example, if the membrane is being depolarized, the greater the stimulus, the greater the __________.
For example, if the __________ is being depolarized, the greater the stimulus, the greater the depolarization.
For example, if the membrane is being depolarized, the greater the __________, the greater the depolarization.
If and only if neurons are __________ __________, the membrane potential reaches a level called the threshold potential, which is approximately 55 - 55 millivolts in a neuron.
If and only if neurons are sufficiently depolarized, the membrane potential reaches a level called the threshold potential, which is approximately 55 - 55 __________ in a neuron.
If and only if neurons are sufficiently depolarized, the membrane potential reaches a level called the __________ __________, which is approximately 55 - 55 millivolts in a neuron.
If and only if neurons are sufficiently depolarized, the __________ __________ reaches a level called the threshold potential, which is approximately 55 - 55 millivolts in a neuron.

In a __________ __________, the first part of the axon, the cone - shaped axon hillock or initial segment, is often referred to as the trigger zone because it contains many such voltage - gated sodium channels.
Sodium ions diffuse inward through the open sodium channels, down their concentration gradient, aided by the __________ of the sodium ions to the negative charges on the inside of the membrane.
Sodium ions diffuse inward through the open sodium channels, down their concentration __________, aided by the attraction of the sodium ions to the negative charges on the inside of the membrane.
Sodium ions diffuse inward through the open sodium channels, down their concentration gradient, aided by the attraction of the sodium ions to the negative charges on the inside of the __________.
As the sodium ions diffuse inward, the __________ __________ at the trigger zone changes from its resting value and momentarily becomes positive on the inside.
At the peak of the action potential, the __________ __________ may reach +30 + 30 millivolts or more.
As potassium ions diffuse outward, down their concentration gradient and through the open potassium channels, the inside becomes __________ __________ once more.
As potassium ions diffuse outward, down their concentration gradient and through the open __________ __________, the inside becomes negatively charged once more.
As __________ __________ diffuse outward, down their concentration gradient and through the open potassium channels, the inside becomes negatively charged once more.
As potassium ions diffuse outward, down their __________ __________ and through the open potassium channels, the inside becomes negatively charged once more.
The membrane is thus __________.
The __________ is thus repolarized.
These actions __________ __________ the resting potential, which remains in the resting state until it is stimulated again.
The number of sodium and potassium ions crossing the membrane during an action potential is extremely small, although the __________ __________ is quite significant.
The number of sodium and __________ __________ crossing the membrane during an action potential is extremely small, although the bioelectric effect is quite significant.
The number of sodium and potassium ions crossing the __________ during an action potential is extremely small, although the bioelectric effect is quite significant.
The active transport mechanism Na+/K+pump in the membrane restores and maintains the __________ __________ of sodium and potassium ions.
The active transport mechanism Na+/K+pump in the membrane __________ and maintains the original concentrations of sodium and potassium ions.
Most __________ - gated channels in a neuron are along the axon, especially at the trigger zone.

An action potential at the trigger zone causes a __________ __________ to flow a short distance down the axon, which stimulates the adjacent membrane to reach its threshold level, triggering another action potential.
This sequence of events results in the conduction of the action potential along the axon __________ __________ in amplitude, even if the axon branches.
This sequence of events results in the __________ of the action potential along the axon without decreasing in amplitude, even if the axon branches.
This sequence of events results in the conduction of the action potential along the axon without decreasing in __________, even if the axon branches.
In the muscle fiber, __________ at the motor end plate triggers an action potential that spreads over the surface of the fiber and down into its transverse tubules.
The number of action potentials per second that an axon can generate is limited, because during an action potential, that part of the axon becomes __________ to another threshold stimulus.
The number of action __________ per second that an axon can generate is limited, because during an action potential, that part of the axon becomes unresponsive to another threshold stimulus.
The number of action potentials per second that an axon can generate is limited, because during an action potential, that part of the axon becomes unresponsive to another __________ __________.
The number of action potentials per second that an axon __________ __________ is limited, because during an action potential, that part of the axon becomes unresponsive to another threshold stimulus.

During the __________ __________ __________, which lasts about 1/1,000 of a second, the axon 's voltage - gated sodium channels are temporarily not responsive at all, and the axon can not be stimulated.
During the absolute refractory period, which lasts about 1/1,000 of a second, the axon 's voltage - gated sodium channels are temporarily not __________ at all, and the axon can not be stimulated.
A relative refractory period follows, as the membrane __________ __________ resting potential.
A __________ __________ __________ follows, as the membrane reestablishes its resting potential.
A relative refractory period follows, as the __________ reestablishes its resting potential.
Rapidly, the intensity of stimulation required to trigger an impulse decreases until the axon 's __________ __________ is restored.
Rapidly, the intensity of __________ required to trigger an impulse decreases until the axon 's original excitability is restored.
Rapidly, the __________ of stimulation required to trigger an impulse decreases until the axon 's original excitability is restored.
The __________ __________ limits how many action potentials may be generated in a neuron in a given period.
The refractory period limits how __________ __________ __________ may be generated in a neuron in a given period.

The __________ __________ also ensures that an action potential is conducted in only one direction, down the axon, because the area upstream from where the action potential has just occurred is still in the refractory period from the previous action potential.

The refractory period also ensures that an action potential is conducted in only one direction, down the axon, because the area upstream from where the action potential has just occurred is still in the __________ __________ from the previous action potential.
An __________ __________ conducts an impulse over its entire surface.
Myelin contains a __________ __________ of lipid that excludes water and water - soluble substances.
Thus, myelin prevents almost all flow of ions through the membrane that it encloses and serves as an __________ __________.
Thus, myelin prevents almost all flow of ions through the __________ that it encloses and serves as an electrical insulator.
It might seem that the myelin sheath would prevent __________ of an impulse, and this would be true if the sheath were continuous along the length of the axon.
However, nodes of __________ between Schwann cells or oligodendrocytes interrupt the sheath.
At these nodes, the axon membrane has channels for sodium and potassium ions that open during a __________ __________.
At these nodes, the __________ __________ has channels for sodium and potassium ions that open during a threshold depolarization.
This causes a __________ __________ to flow away from the trigger zone through the cytoplasm of the axon.
This causes a bioelectric current to flow away from the trigger zone through the __________ of the axon.
As this local current reaches the first node, it stimulates the membrane to its threshold level, and an action potential occurs there, sending a __________ __________ to the next node downstream.

As this local current reaches the first node, it stimulates the membrane to its threshold level, and an action potential occurs there, sending a bioelectric current to the __________ __________ __________.
As this local current reaches the first node, it stimulates the membrane to its __________ __________, and an action potential occurs there, sending a bioelectric current to the next node downstream.
As this local current reaches the first node, it stimulates the __________ to its threshold level, and an action potential occurs there, sending a bioelectric current to the next node downstream.
The diameter of the axon affects the speed of impulse __________ -- the greater the diameter, the faster the impulse.
Released __________ __________ diffuse across the synaptic cleft and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic cell membrane.
Released neurotransmitter molecules diffuse across the synaptic cleft and bind to __________ on the postsynaptic cell membrane.
Released neurotransmitter molecules diffuse across the synaptic cleft and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic cell __________.
Released neurotransmitter molecules diffuse across the __________ __________ and bind to receptors on the postsynaptic cell membrane.
When __________ bind these receptors, they cause ion channels in the postsynaptic cells to open.
When neurotransmitters bind these __________, they cause ion channels in the postsynaptic cells to open.
Ion channels that respond to neurotransmitter molecules are called __________ __________, in contrast to the voltage - gated ion channels that participate in action potentials.
Ion channels that respond to neurotransmitter molecules are called chemically gated, in contrast to the voltage - gated ion channels that participate in __________ __________.
__________ __________ can depolarize or hyperpolarize the receiving cell membrane.
Synaptic potentials can depolarize or hyperpolarize the receiving __________ __________.
For example, if a __________ binds to a postsynaptic receptor and opens sodium ion channels, the ions diffuse inward, depolarizing the membrane, possibly triggering an action potential.
For example, if a neurotransmitter binds to a __________ __________ and opens sodium ion channels, the ions diffuse inward, depolarizing the membrane, possibly triggering an action potential.
For example, if a neurotransmitter binds to a postsynaptic receptor and opens sodium ion channels, the ions diffuse inward, depolarizing the __________, possibly triggering an action potential.
In this case, negative chloride ions enter the cell opposing the __________.
In this case, __________ __________ __________ enter the cell opposing the depolarization.
In this case, negative chloride ions enter the cell __________ the depolarization.
The integrated sum of the EPSPs and __________ determines whether an action potential results.
This is usually in a proximal region of the axon, but in some sensory neurons it may be in the __________ __________ __________.
This is usually in a __________ __________ of the axon, but in some sensory neurons it may be in the distal peripheral process.
When an action potential passes along the membrane of a synaptic knob, it increases the membrane 's __________ to calcium ions by opening calcium ion channels.
When an action potential passes along the __________ of a synaptic knob, it increases the membrane 's permeability to calcium ions by opening calcium ion channels.
Calcium ions diffuse inward, and in response, some of the synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release their contents by __________ into the synaptic cleft.
Calcium ions diffuse inward, and in response, some of the synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic __________ and release their contents by exocytosis into the synaptic cleft.
Calcium ions diffuse inward, and in response, some of the synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release their __________ by exocytosis into the synaptic cleft.
Calcium ions diffuse inward, and in response, some of the synaptic vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane and release their contents by exocytosis into the __________ __________.
A vesicle becomes part of the cell __________ after it releases its neurotransmitter.
__________ eventually returns the membrane material to the cytoplasm, where it can provide material to form new secretory vesicles.
Endocytosis eventually returns the membrane material to the __________, where it can provide material to form new secretory vesicles.
Endocytosis eventually returns the membrane material to the cytoplasm, where it can provide material to form __________ __________ __________.
Endocytosis eventually returns the __________ __________ to the cytoplasm, where it can provide material to form new secretory vesicles.
__________ __________ are transported back into the synaptic knob of the presynaptic neuron or into nearby neurons or neuroglia, in a process called reuptake.
Other neurotransmitters are transported back into the __________ __________ of the presynaptic neuron or into nearby neurons or neuroglia, in a process called reuptake.
Other neurotransmitters are transported back into the synaptic knob of the presynaptic neuron or into nearby neurons or neuroglia, in a process called __________.
This enzyme is found in __________ in the synaptic knob.
Destruction or removal of neurotransmitter prevents continuous __________ of the postsynaptic neuron.
Destruction or removal of neurotransmitter __________ continuous stimulation of the postsynaptic neuron.
Substance P is a __________ that consists of eleven amino acids and is widely distributed.
__________ __________ is a neuropeptide that consists of eleven amino acids and is widely distributed.
It functions as a __________ in the neurons that conduct impulses associated with pain into the spinal cord and on to the brain.
It functions as a neurotransmitter in the neurons that conduct __________ associated with pain into the spinal cord and on to the brain.
The way the nervous __________ __________, processes, and responds to information reflects, in part, the organization of neurons and axons in the brain and spinal cord.
__________, which are the neurons completely within the CNS, are organized into neuronal pools.
Interneurons, which are the neurons completely within the CNS, are organized into __________ __________.
These are groups of __________ that synapse with each other and perform a common function, even though their cell bodies may be in different parts of the CNS.

Repeated impulses on an excitatory presynaptic neuron may cause that neuron to release more __________ in response to a single impulse, making it more likely to bring the postsynaptic cell to threshold.
